info.name: Arlo and Isla

info.description:
You are Arlo and Isla, two sibling cats that love nothing more than knocking things off the shelf. Not to break them, but to store them! Walk Arlo and Isla around the board collecting treasures that will score you more points than your opponents.
PS. There's only one cat icon because they're inseperable.
info.ruleText:
Click to sit at one of the 6 player spaces. Click and drag the cat to a space underneath one of the first 3 cards starting with the upper left corner. Whichever card you stop at, you will collect and place below your name in one of your 6 holders. The next player then moves the cat anywhere from 1-3 spaces and collects whatever card they stop at, and so on. Once all 6 colors of a card, or 6 suits of a card are collected, then scoring takes place. Increase your score by the number of collected cards you have that have just scored. The bank will then reduce by the number you added. 

Example: Someone has just collected the last spade card from the board. You have a yellow and a blue spade. You score 2 points. Later, someone collected the last yellow card from the board. You only have your yellow spade from earlier, you score 1 point for that card now since it is yellow.

As cards get collected, empty spaces will be on the board, do not count those empty spaces as your 1-3 movement. If you like, you can consolidate the cards on the board to make it easier to review what remains. 

Generally, the game ends when a card is taken that causes scoring to empty the bank. In the event that the last card causes a scoring of 2 different attributes, such as suit and color, then all applicable points are distributed even though the bank is empty. High score wins. There are no official tie breakers. 


Variants:

Alex Randolph suggests a variant, Veleno, that your score is equal to your points plus the next player in turn order from you. You can try this scoring method with any of the variants available.

Kid Variant: For a simpler version with children, you can remove one color and one shape so that there are only 25 tiles to collect. The bank is then also reduced to 25.

Advanced Variant
This version was first introduced in the 1994 book New Games in Old Rome by Reiner Knizia and later became Bunte Runde. It adds more complexity with both positive and negative scoring.

In this version, every card has shapes, colors, and numbers 1-5. The game is played the same way as the base game: move the cat 1-3 spaces and pick a card. However, when you collect all the cards of a certain suit (color/shape), you immediately score the total value of the cards in that suit you have collected.

For example, if you collect the 5th red card and have the 1, 3, and 4 of red, you score 8 points. If another player has the red 2 and 5, they score 7 points.

The game ends when the last card with a value is taken. If that card is also the last of a suit, scoring happens in two steps:

  1. First, everyone scores positive points for the cards in that suit.

  2. Then, negative points are scored for any cards of the value that was just taken.

For example, if the red 5 is the last card taken, the player with the red 5 scores positive points for the red suit, then everyone with 5‚Äôs scores negative points.

A player can end the game with negative points in this variant.

Note: This variant is for 5 players only and does not use a "bank" of points. Since the game is short, you can decide to play multiple rounds or play until someone reaches a set number of points (e.g., 50 points).

Advanced Variant 2
This variant uses the same rules as the "Advanced Variant," but with an additional rule:

Once during the game, each player can choose to turn a card they just picked face down instead of face up. This face-down card's suit will never score positively, and its value will never score negatively. Game end is triggered the same way, with all of one value being collected from the central area. 

This rule is not recommended in a 5-player game because it can lead to situations where no points are scored, especially if a card of each value and suit is turned face down. If only one card of each value is turned down (but not one card of each suit), positive points can still be scored. In this scenario, the game ends when the final card is collected from the available cards.

Advanced Variant 3
This variant is similar to "Advanced Variant" with some changes to the scoring rules.

In this version, when the last card of a value is taken, it is scored in reverse rank. So, the 5‚Äôs score as 1 point, and the 1‚Äôs score as 5 points.

When the last card of a suit is taken, it is scored in the usual way (a 5 counts as 5 points, a 1 counts as 1 point).

The game ends when at least one value and one suit have been scored. For example, if the 3‚Äôs are scored first, then the 2‚Äôs, and then the reds, the game ends when the reds are scored because at least one value and one suit have been scored.

If a card triggers scoring for both a value and a suit, both are scored.
info.helpText: Click to sit at one of the 6 player spaces. Click and drag the cat to a space underneath the one of the first 3 cards and drag the card to one of the 6 holders underneath your name. When you click the + or - button next to your score, it will also increment or decrement the bank of available points in the game.
